ygData.subject: Question Re: Application of HyperNEAT Approach

Subject: Question Re: Application of HyperNEAT Approach
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=200957992; y=N-4nt6DZX28MYJXIhds09AIpyTJp188GgBxim1PMNTrvcO_JoA

To answer your question directly, I think that the closest choice 
would be=
 'b', although there is some truth in all of the choices.

Basically, I loo=
k at the function of the CPPN Network as adding a 
layer of abstraction bet=
ween the real-world sensor input and the 
neural network.

For example, in =
the NERO project they used rtNEAT to evolve an AI for 
agents in a sandbox =
battlefield.  A subset of the sensory inputs to a 
NERO agent is a radar, d=
ivided into wedges.  An ad-hoc approach was 
used to covert "there are two =
guys in this wedge, one of them is 
close and shooting at me, and one of th=
em is far away" into a single 
number that represents "threat" in that wedg=
e.

Why not just make all wedges extremely thin, so that each wedge could 
=
only hold at most one enemy?  The obvious answer is that it would be 
extre=
mely difficult to train a neural network which had 360,000 
inputs, one for=
 every .0001 degree slice of the pie.

HyperNEAT addresses this concern by =
elevating the problem to a level 
above individual sensors.  As David D'Amb=
rosio showed in his paper, 
his CPPN evolved a "concept" of food gathering,=
 which was expressed 
at many resolutions.  In my paper, I evolved a vision=
 system which 
could operate at any resolution.  By abstracting away specif=
ic 
sensors, we have narrowed the gap between the real-world inputs and 
th=
e inputs to a learning system.

Now instead of coming up with ways to creat=
e sensor data, we can 
shift to coming up with ways to divide data up into =
dimensions.  One 
important idea is that, although we have used physical ge=
ometry in 
both of our projects, anything which has a vector of values can =
be 
considered a "point", with each of those values lying on 
some "dimensi=
on".  Thus, every problem could have geometric 
properties, even though the=
 idea that there's some numerical distance 
between "happy man" and "angry =
sewer rat" seems far-fetched.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.ca=
rl@...> wrote:
>
> Jason,
>    Would it be correct to say that the applicat=
ion of the HyperNEAT 
> approach to a problem, would be:
> 
> a) the evolut=
ion of a CPPN network with problem inputs and outputs 
> configured as inpu=
ts to the CPPN, and the output of which being the 
> problem connection wei=
ght,
> 
> b) the expansion of available activation functions within the CPP=
N 
> nodes, allowing exploitation of underlying functional relationships 
>=
 of the problem inputs and outputs, and
> 
> c) anticipated computational s=
avings due to evolution of only the 
> CPPN, and only evaluation overhead o=
f the problem network(?)
> 
>    I'm just trying to identify the applicabil=
ity, given the 
apparent 
> increase in dimensions associated with problems=
 in which actual 
> geometry (as opposed to problem parameter space), is ap=
plicable. 
> Thanks for publishing your work and code.
> 
> Thanks,
>    An=
dy Carl
